Probst reported two other decisions reached by the FAE at this meeting which
indirectly affect the NAEB. A proposal by Ralph Steetle to continue a second
year grant to the Joint Committee on Educational Television was agreed to.
After consultation with Steetle, Probst presented to Mr. Fletcher a request
that Mr. Fletcher authorize the current JCET to pay the old ad hoc JCET debts
from the $9,000.00 that will be unexpended in the current yearns budget. Mr.
Fletcher agreed to present this request to his Board and it will undoubtedly
be approved. Thus the old ad hoc JCET debts of about $4*800.00 which now
hang over the head of the present JCET will be discharged. Everybody con¬
cerned in this matter is pleased with getting this done.
Siegel asked whether a second year grant would be made for the Lowell program-
ming project. Wheatley, Hull, and Probst said that their judgment was that
the FAE would make this grant. They said, hoxtfever, that Fletcher did not
provide an opportunity for discussion of the specific amount. Fletcher did
indicate that the second grant would probably be made at the July meeting of
the Board of Trustees of the Fund. Fletcher had indicated satisfaction with
the general areas of the program project and believed they should be continued.
Probst also commented on the value of a man like Goldschmidt in our project.
Fletcher has met and talked to Goldschmidt several times, and is impressed
that we have been able to hire a man of his capabilities. Probst went on to
say that Goldschmidt was terrific, that he is the type to make an outstanding
university president and is one of the leading young social anthropologists in
the country. Probst said that the whole past and future success of the project
depends upon our ability to identify and persuade brilliant and intelligent
people to work for us.
At Pasadena, Fletcher stated his desire to discuss the problems and opportunities
of our project with the NAEB. Siegel said that Fletcher has been invited to
speak at the Columbus meeting and has accepted. He will have a chance to talk
to the NAEB board during its Thursday meeting and will share the speakers9
duties with Chairman Walker of the FCC at the annual NAEB luncheon on Friday.
This means that Fletcher will get a chance to inform the entire NAEB membership
of his plans and problems.
Probst reported that he told Fletcher at Pasadena that the Adult Education
Committee did not want the responsibility of administering a second year grant.
Miles asked if this brought any reaction from Fletcher. Probst replied that
Fletcher was disturbed by the request—that he thought both the Adult Education
Committee and the Lowell Foundation had been very successful in a difficult
and creative job. Wheatley reported also that Lowell did not want to handle
the funds another year, and that this had been reported to Fletcher.
The question was raised as to when the Adult Education Committee should meet
with the NAEB Board of Trustees to report on the projects and answer any further
questions that the Board may have which are not answered in the minutes of the
committee’s meetings. Siegel said that the next NAEB Board meeting at Columbus,
Ohio, would be the proper and desirable place for a joint meeting with the Adult
Education Committee, and that since it will then be three months since the two
groups met together on January IB-19, it would certainly be desirable to hold
a joint meeting in Columbus. Siegel formally extended an invitation to the
members of the Adult Education Committee to meet with the Board at that time.
